The [British] Library respects the intellectual property rights, including moral rights, of rights holders and makes all reasonable effort to contact and consult rights owners, including, where appropriate, communities directly, or via local community organisations. Given the importance of the historical record, and the fact that that some of our digitised collections include materials that are sensitive to particular communities and groups, we ask that any use of the digitised collections is undertaken with the appropriate care. Irrespective of its copyright status, items and/or collections should not be altered or used in ways that might be derogatory to the originating individuals or communities. notesStmt.note: Leaves stuck on paper (modern restoration). Folios damaged at the beginning and at the end. Only about half of folio 212 preserved.

Appended to the manuscript are the following fragments, originally portions of other manuscripts: folios 195r, 204v - Azharot of Solomon ibn Gabirol, followed by a series of hosh῾anot; folios 205r-211r - Keter malkhut of Solomon ibn Gabirol; folios 211v-212v - two poetical pieces; folio 213 - a calendar leaf on the years 5492-5505 (1732-1745). The first three parts belong most probably to the 17th century.Folios 44-45, which originally belonged to another manuscript, are now bound with the present manuscript just before shaḥarit of Rosh ha-Shanah. This fragment is also of 17th century. Folio 44r has a note, in a fading ink, of a viduy after the passing of Rabi Yehudah Zeruvavel.Folio 1r: a note of a former owner, Yosef Ben Shalom ben Yesha῾, written over an erasure originally occupied by another name.
Manuscript description based on Margoliouth, G.: Catalogue of the Hebrew and Samaritan Manuscripts in the British Museum, London 1965.

msContents.summary: A service book, according to the Yemenite rite.

msItem.title: A section on the form of prayer

collation.p: Quires of originally 10 leaves each, marked by catchwords at the end (mostly not preserved).

scriptDesc.scriptNote: Yemenite semi-cursive script, punctuated, of the 17th century.

binding.p: BM/BL in-house. Spine: 'Prayer Book. Hebrew. Brit. Mus. Oriental 2389.'

history.provenance: Acquisition: Moses Wilhelm Shapira (b. 1830, d. 1884), a antiquities dealer of Jerusalem: purchased by the British Museum from him on 23 July 1881: inscribed, folio [214v].
